qas.question: Do antibiotics interact with birth control pills?

answers.text: The majority of studies indicate antibiotics do interfere with contraceptive pills

qas.question: What percentage of birth control pill failure is attributed to antibiotics?
What are the potential effects on intestinal flora?

answers.text: reduced absorption of estrogens in the colon

qas.question: Have these potential effects been proven through testing?
What do physicians recommend to counteract this potential issue?

plausible_answers.text: The majority of studies indicate antibiotics do interfere with contraceptive pills,

qas.question: Do antibiotics interact with intestinal flora?
What percentage of birth control pill failure is attributed to estrogens?

context: <a0_0><b12_0>The majority of studies indicate <a9_0>antibiotics do interfere<a9_0/> with <a5_0>contraceptive pills<a5_0/><a0_0/>,<b12_0/> such as clinical studies that suggest the failure rate of contraceptive pills caused by antibiotics is very low (<a1_0><a6_0><a10_0>about <b13_0>1%<b13_0/><a10_0/><a6_0/><a1_0/>). In cases where antibacterials have been suggested to affect the efficiency of birth control pills, such as for the broad-spectrum antibacterial rifampicin, these cases may be due to an increase in the activities of hepatic liver enzymes' causing increased breakdown of the pill's active ingredients. Effects on the intestinal flora, which might result in <a2_0>reduced <a7_0><b16_0>absorption of estrogens<b16_0/><a7_0/> in the colon<a2_0/>, have also been suggested, but such suggestions have been <a3_0><b14_0>inconclusive and controversial<b14_0/><a3_0/>. Clinicians have recommended that <a4_0><a11_0><b15_0>extra contraceptive measures<b15_0/><a11_0/><a4_0/> be applied during therapies using antibacterials that are suspected to interact with <a8_0>oral contraceptives<a8_0/>.
